data.title: Tokheim Services Group
data.text:
Tokheim-OPWPublic (Dover Corp DOV- NYSE)IndustryManufacturingFounded1901[1]HeadquartersAustin, Texas

Key people

Mike McCann, (Default Acting President)

OPWProductsFuel Supply SystemsOwnerDover Corp since, January 7, 20162,800Websitewww.tokheim.com

Tokheim is a global manufacturer of fuel dispensers. It is one of the world's leading manufacturers and servicers of fuel dispensing equipment. The group has operations in many countries and offers fuel dispensers and pumps, retail automation systems, payment terminals, media devices, replacement parts and upgrade kits, and support services including service station construction and maintenance.[2]

Products[edit]

Welcome to the group website of TSG. Here you will find all the information about the TSG group and what we offer globally. Please choose your location to find the products and services.

Tokheim AdBlue dispenser in France.

Tokheim designs and assembles fuel dispensing systems and electronic data and payment automation systems for the global fuel retail systems and services market. Tokheim services include installation, maintenance, construction, and refurbishment of fuel dispensers. The company's products and services are used in over 40,000 service station and sold to over 350 customers from major oil companies to independent distributors. Customers include Esso, Total, Shell, Intermarché, Carrefour and BP. Tokheim has over 5,400 employees[3] through 33 wholly owned sales and services subsidiaries in Europe, Asia and Africa. For the fiscal year ended April 2012, the company had sales of €643 million.[4][5]

History[edit]

The company is named after the Norwegian John J. Tokheim. Working in a hardware store in Iowa, he was conscious of the dangers of storing fuel. In 1898, he designed an exterior storage system, served by a modified water pump. This development had the advantage of allowing him to accurately meter the delivery of fuel. In 1901, he patented the world's first vehicle fuel dispenser.[6]

The popularity of his invention, the Tokheim Dome Oil Pump, led to the founding of the Tokheim Manufacturing Company in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, in 1901. In 1918, a group of executives from Fort Wayne, Indiana, purchased the company and moved the business there. It later grew to become Tokheim Corporation. In the 1970s, Tokheim unsuccessfully marketed a bicycle gearing system, an alternative to the derailleur.[7] In 2003, Tokheim Corporation's North America operations were acquired by First Reserve, while its international assets and subsidiaries were acquired by Tokheim S.A.S., owned 94% by AXA Private Equity and 6% by a management team. In 2005, Tokheim S.A.S. was acquired by Cognetas (previously named Electra Partners Europe), together with the management of Tokheim.[1][8]

In January 2016, Tokheim was acquired by OPW, and together form one of the largest fuel retail equipment providers in the world.

References[edit]

^ abTokheim web site, History. Retrieved 11 June 2019.

^Tokheim web site, About Us. Retrieved 11 June 2019.

^Tokheim Company website

^Motion Equity Partners press release

^Tokheim Company website: Facts and Figures. Retrieved 11 June 2019.

^T. Coulibaly (2007), Il y a un siècle, l'automobile, pp. 19-20

^Tokheim gearing system: They Say You Want a (Shifting) Revolution

^Scott Anderson: 'The Gas Pump Showcase', Petroleum Collectibles Monthly, November 2002.

Retrieved from 'https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tokheim&oldid=901926437'
